Respected Quebec public figure Charles Taylor wrote an open letter* to LaPresse, in which he spoke about the recent growth of specifically anti-muslim activites in Quebec.  He described a:

“proliferation of attacks, especially against muslim women wearing a veil – attacks ranging from hate speech all the way to physical assaults. 

“These reactions were caused by a minority of citizens already nursing hostility towards immigrants in general and muslims in particular, but who previously dared not go public with it. The debate on the Charter of Values had the effect of reducing their inhibitions or even eliminating them altogether. . . “ 

He ends on a positive tone: “Let’s give ourselves the time and opportunity for reconciliation [. . .] The new Quebec ‘us’ is bigger now.” 

So is the new Canada.

input.text:
CSIS highlights white supremacist threat ahead of radical Islam

Citing recent academic research, the unclassified documents note extreme right-wing and white supremacist ideology has been the “main ideological source” for 17 per cent of so-called lone wolf attacks worldwide.

Islamic extremism accounted for 15 per cent of such attacks, the document noted, while left-wing extremism and “black power” groups followed with 13 per cent. Anti-abortion activism (8 per cent) and nationalism/separatism (7 per cent) rounded out the list, while in 40 per cent of cases there was no clear ideological motivation.

"The threat from the far right in Canada is real," Ryan Scrivens, one of the new report's authors and PhD candidate at Simon Fraser University, told VICE News. "It doesn't get the same kind of attention and publicity that Islamic extremist groups get, but they have, historically, done more damage in Canada."
